rationale: Both mentions refer to the same concept of false or misleading information on social media, differing only in type granularity and phrasing.
“Fake news” is a specific subtype of misleading content and is distinct from the broader concept of misinformation.
“Information” here denotes general content/data on platforms and is conceptually broader than misinformation or fake news.
“Rumors” are a specific form of unverified content and not identical to other listed phenomena like misinformation or propaganda.
“Conspiracy theories” are a distinct type of narrative content and should remain separate from other misinformation-related entities.
“Propaganda” is a specific category of biased or manipulative content and not strictly synonymous with misinformation.
“Serious real-world consequences” refers to outcomes or impacts, not an information type, so it should remain a separate entity.
Both mentions of 'likes' refer to the same social media engagement action, differing only in minor wording and type hint, so they should be unified.
‘shares’ is a distinct social media action (redistributing content) and is not duplicated elsewhere in this group.
‘emojis’ are distinct expressive icons and are not duplicated or conflicting with other entities.
‘comments’ are user-written responses and represent a separate feature with no duplicate in this set.
Refers specifically to adverse impacts on mental health from social media; distinct from self-esteem, inadequacy, or comparison as separate effects.
Denotes harmful impact on self-esteem, which is a specific construct separate from overall mental health and other psychological states mentioned.
Captures a particular subjective emotional state (feeling inadequate), not interchangeable with the broader constructs of mental health or self-esteem.
Describes a psychological process (social comparison), conceptually distinct from downstream symptoms like low self-esteem or inadequacy.
Represents the broad category of mental health implications of social media use, which is more general than and not identical to the other specific effects listed.
Both mentions describe the same phenomenon of shallow, surface-level communication on social media; one is a longer phrasing of the other in the same conceptual context.
This refers to a value preference (prioritizing volume of interactions) rather than the communication pattern itself, so it is conceptually distinct and should remain separate.
Distinct process concept focused on increasing the reach and impact of individuals’ messages; no duplicate mentions match it exactly.
Represents a specific process (growing visibility of marginalized groups) that is related to but not identical to amplification of voices or empowerment; no exact duplicate.
Denotes the social group itself, not the process of gaining visibility; clearly different type and role from related process entities.

Represents the value/practice of inclusion, which is conceptually distinct from diversity and other entities here.

Describes a broad group of diverse voices, which is not limited to marginalized groups and thus distinct from related entities.

Refers to the abstract value/practice of inclusion, which is conceptually distinct from both diversity and diverse voices.
Refers to a group of social actors ('diverse voices') rather than the abstract values of diversity or inclusion, so it should remain separate.
Represents a distinct communication pattern concept (superficial communication on social media) not duplicated by any other entity in the group.
Refers specifically to the social media feature 'likes', which is not repeated elsewhere in the group.
Denotes the specific action 'shares' on social platforms, distinct from likes, emojis, or broader communication patterns.
Refers to 'emojis' as a separate interaction feature and is not a duplicate of any other entity.
Captures the abstract value preference 'quantity over quality', which is conceptually different from features like likes, shares, or emojis.
This refers specifically to the technical/social capability of connecting across physical distance, distinct from general benefits or the quality of relationships.
This captures the broader benefit of increased connectivity via social media, which is related to but not identical with cross-distance capability or the depth of relationships.
This focuses on the quality of relationships (“deeper, more genuine” connections), which is conceptually different from mere connectivity or distance-agnostic communication.
Both mentions describe detrimental impacts of social media on mental health, differing only in phrasing and context, so they represent the same underlying concept.
A distinct psychological state (persistent need for validation) that is not semantically identical to any other entity.
Refers specifically to the platform feature 'comments', which is distinct from all other psychological or health-related entities.
Targets self-esteem specifically, which is a narrower construct than overall mental health and should remain separate.
Represents a specific psychological state (feeling inadequate) distinct from the broader mental health impact entities.
Denotes the process of social comparison, which is conceptually different from the health outcomes and should remain a separate node.
Represents a process/concept (human communication in contemporary society), distinct from a time period; no conflicting mentions to justify merging or modification.
Represents a time period (the contemporary digital era), not a communication process; clearly distinct from the other entity so it should be kept separate.
Refers specifically to the beneficial societal outcomes enabled by social media, distinct from social media’s capabilities themselves.
Represents the influence and capabilities of social media, which is conceptually different from the resulting positive societal change.
Refers broadly to the collective social structure and community; distinct concept from specific effects of social media.
Represents a distinct conceptual category (beneficial impacts of social media) and is not synonymous with the other entities.
Represents a separate conceptual category (harmful impacts of social media) and should remain distinct from the positive effects and from society itself.
Distinct concept referring to online social platforms as a category, not duplicated elsewhere in the group.
Clearly represents the specific process of citizen journalism, which is separate from other entities like social media or user-generated content.
Refers to a specific type/category of content created by users, distinct from processes (citizen journalism) and platforms (social media).
Represents the information type 'news', which is conceptually distinct from its distribution channels or creators.
Denotes legacy news organizations and channels as a category, not overlapping in meaning with other entities.
Describes an audience group rather than a platform, process, or content type, so it remains a separate concept.
Represents the general concept/category of social media platforms; no conflicting variants to merge with.
Refers specifically to the changing environment or context around social media rather than the platform category itself, so it should remain distinct.
Captures a behavioral concept (how platforms are used) that is clearly distinct from both the platforms and the broader landscape.
Represents a broad concept of interpersonal relationships as shaped by social media, distinct from the more specific conditions and interaction types listed.
Describes a specific negative condition (lack of meaningful interaction) rather than a type of relationship or interaction, so it should remain separate.
Refers to authentic, deep interpersonal connections, a distinct relationship concept not identical to general relationships or online/face-to-face modalities.
Clearly denotes relationships maintained primarily online, a specific modality distinct from face-to-face interaction and general relationships.
Represents in-person, face-to-face interaction, a distinct interaction mode from online relationships or abstract relationship quality concepts.
Refers specifically to patterns of human actions and conduct; distinct concept from perceptions or interpretations of the world.
Refers to how individuals interpret and understand the world; conceptually different from behaviors, so it should remain a separate entity.
Facebook is a distinct social media platform and not interchangeable with the other entities.
Twitter is a distinct social networking and microblogging platform separate from Facebook and Instagram.
Instagram is a distinct photo and video sharing platform and should not be merged with Facebook or Twitter.
Represents the distinct social group of friends, different from family and acquaintances.
Represents the distinct social group of family/relatives, not interchangeable with friends or acquaintances.
Represents the distinct social group of acquaintances, conceptually separate from friends and family.
Distinct communication method (real-time text) separate from video calls and other features.
Distinct communication method (real-time audiovisual) and not overlapping conceptually with instant messaging or platform features.
Represents a general class of platform functionalities, not the same as specific communication methods or content types.
Represents a specific type of shared content (status posts), distinct from photos and communication methods.
Represents image-based content, clearly distinct from textual updates and communication features.
Represents a distinct content type (personal reflections/opinions) shared on social media, clearly separate from emotional or social states.
Denotes a psychological state of emotional proximity, which is conceptually distinct from both content types and broader community-level conditions.
Refers to a social condition of belonging/community, different from individual psychological closeness and from specific shared content.
